text: what you're looking at is a fighting
style called the 52 blocks it spot
martial art and part boxing its
practitioners say that 52 was born out
of black prize fighting at the turn of
the century and then developed in street
culture its fans say it should become a
recognized artform defensively and
offensively the 52 never stops moving
the torso is constantly shifting and
turning its boxing with an edge its
footwork and tighter guard were
developed with bare fists and confined
spaces in mind like a cell or a narrow
hallway
Daniel Marx teaches 52 blocks and is an
advocate for the sport which he says
does belong inside the ring I'm hearing
the term dirty boxing a lot it's no such
thing as dirty boxing unless there are
set rules that you can't use a certain
technique then what you would do would
be considered dirty but in the sense of
self-defense or boxing or fighting then
whatever you can use to negate a
person's technique in a sense is
considered legal since the techniques of
the 52 have been handed down through
word of mouth it's history is a bit
murky it doesn't have recorded
certificates or texts the way martial
arts from Japan or China do several
years ago videos began popping up on
YouTube demonstrating the 52 and for the
first time many could see it in action
light burly posted early videos he
teaches and trains in New York's East
Village and has a background in boxing
in Chinese martial arts but lately the
52 has become his main focus
first time I seen 50 tools in Far
Rockaway Queens of fights were the way
men were men no there was nothing about
bats knives guns guns were definitely
totally off-limits
it was strictly pretty much a handstand
you try to lead your opponent into
surprises so that way it doesn't make it
too repetitive
you can't just dance in front of
opponent mr. Markson mr. Burley hoped
that as more people become exposed to
the 52 acceptance in the organized
fighting world will follow with more
schools teaching the 52 and even
recognition from the sport fighting
circuit
